ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A great course to take if you want to learn some legal content in Spanish.
Very good understanding of comparative legal analysis, especially when comparing the common law to the civil law systems.
Learned about legal systems all over the world.  Had current events discussions in Spanish with classmates.  Watched lots of legal TV :)
Legal spanish diction and a better understanding of conversational Spanish.
I learned to speak about legal manners and about legal terms in Spanish.
I developed a significant understanding of the history of the law and its application.

This class was a great way to continue hearing and reading Spanish alongside my other coursework. I most appreciated the constant exposure to new concepts in Spanish -- I think my vocabulary grew because we were learning about elements of the law. I also think it was great exposure to different kinds of accents//speaking styles through the selected media clips.
My vocabulary regarding specific topics was expanded.
I learned so much about the legal systems of various latin-american and  nations. It was such a great experience and Professor Carreras is great!
I gained a new vocabulary in Spanish in regards to law and developed better reading comprehension skills.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The only thing is that Prof Carreras is a tad soft when she speaks, which with a mask and in Spanish made lectures hard to follow at times.

Strengths: Professor Carreras is so sweet and accommodating.  The syllabus is filled with lots of interesting topics, especially for pre-laws.  Very flexible in assignments and grading.  Weaknesses: As a non-native speaker, I did not feel like there was a ton of opportunity for me to "catch up" to my native-speaking classmates.  This is an L5 class, but the disparity in Spanish skills is still pretty apparent.  Would have appreciated a bit more structure: classroom debates, simulations, etc.  Class periods are also long -- 75 minutes is a lot for a class like this
Fun class, you learn about the continental legal system and how it compares to the Common Law system of law. It is not too much work, but keeps you engaged on a weekly basis.
Excellent relaxed course. Many individuals were not engaged though.
Professor Carreras is a gem thats the classs biggest strength!

Strengths -- The weekly written assignments were about really interesting topics//cases//legal concepts. I think I got the most out of this course by doing the weekly assignments because they helped me think critically and put my ideas on paper in Spanish.
Weaknesses -- The lecture format was not always super engaging. I think classes would have been beneficial to the entire group if they had been more discussion-based. We had a few classes like this at the beginning of the semester.
Open convo, pretty chill. Not very structured and not a lot of info retained.
Everything was great

The weekly assignments were helpful in practicing my Spanish and the debates were interesting. A weakness was that there were not enough opportunities for discussion as the class was a little too big.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Do take!
Yes, a very good way to get an L5 course out of the way, especially if you're working towards the certificate.

Would definitely recommend this course to anyone politically oriented who is looking for an L5 Spanish.  However, would not recommend for someone trying to become fluent in Spanish.  Not really a skill-building course
Yes
Yes, if you are looking for an L5 Spanish class that isn't too much work.
Yes! An easy/fun relaxed L5 course.
Yes! The final paper and course project was especially incredible because it allowed us to explore topics that interested us.
I would definitely recommend! A good way to maintain your spanish fluency.

Yes! It's a super easy class that I felt was still rewarding. The work is minimal, but the material is still interesting if you pay attention. Great to take as a 5th class during an otherwise busy semester! I cannot emphasize this enough: this class never stressed me out. Not once.
Yes, it's a chill L5 and Mercedes is so sweet!
Definitely would recommend this course to others as it was interesting learning about law and the legal system in Spanish.
